content: The "National Park System Reform Act of 1994" is also known as the National Park System Plan. This Act includes the preparation of a plan for the National Park System. The Secretary of the Interior, through the Director of the National Park Service, is tasked with preparing a National Park System Plan to guide the direction of the National Park System. The plan includes goals, criteria for determining resources for inclusion, and identification of adequate resource representation. The National Park System Plan outlines goals, criteria for resource inclusion, and priorities for adding themes and resources to better represent the nation's heritage. It also defines the National Park Service's role in preserving natural areas, industrial America, cultural resources, and providing outdoor recreation opportunities. The National Park System Plan defines goals, criteria for resource inclusion, and priorities for adding themes and resources. It also outlines the distinction between units of the system, affiliated areas, and other areas within the system. The Secretary consults with various agencies and organizations during the plan preparation, including opportunities for public review and comment. The plan must be transmitted to Congress before the end of the third fiscal year after enactment. The Secretary consults with agencies and organizations, including public review and comment opportunities. The plan must be transmitted to Congress within three fiscal years of enactment. SEC. 102. MANAGEMENT REVIEW OF NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. The Secretary will review the National Park System to find better management alternatives, including partnerships with other entities. A report will be developed listing areas where National Park Service management should be changed or ended, considering factors like duplication, resource representation, significance, feasibility, cost, and visitor accessibility. The Secretary will review the National Park System to find better management alternatives, including partnerships with other entities. Recommendations will be made for areas where National Park Service management should be changed or ended based on factors like duplication, resource representation, feasibility, cost, and visitor accessibility. Feasible alternatives to National Park Service management will be identified to protect resources and ensure public access for areas of national significance. The Secretary will consult with various agencies and organizations to develop a list of recommendations for the National Park System. The report will be transmitted to Congress within 1 year after completing the plan outlined in the Act. The report will contain recommendations from the Secretary on modifying or terminating National Park Service management for areas within the National Park System, as well as suggestions for alternative management by other entities. SEC. 103. NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM REVIEW COMMISSION. Establishment of Commission: If the Secretary fails to transmit the report within the specified 1-year period, a National Park System Review Commission will be established to review existing units and suggest modifications or terminations to the management of specific areas. The Commission will consider factors outlined in section 102(a)(2) and present alternative solutions within one year of its establishment. The Commission will develop a list of areas for potential modification or termination, considering specified factors. They will suggest alternative management by entities other than the National Park Service for listed areas, ensuring protection of resources and public access. Consultations will involve various stakeholders for input and feedback. The Commission, consisting of 7 members familiar with the National Park System, will be appointed by the Secretary, Speaker of the House, and President Pro Tem of the Senate. The Commission will elect a chair from its members, and vacancies will be addressed promptly. The Commission, comprising 7 members knowledgeable about the National Park System, will choose a chair from its members. Vacancies will not hinder the Commission's functions, and will be promptly filled. A majority of members will constitute a quorum for meetings held at least quarterly or as called by the chair or majority. Members serve without compensation but are entitled to travel expenses for official business. The Commission established under this section will terminate 90 days after submitting the report to Congress. The Commission can hire staff, with no more than half being National Park Service employees. Other federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission. The Commission may also procure temporary experts and consultants. The Commission established under this section may procure temporary experts and consultants, hold public hearings, make bylaws, rules, and regulations, and use the United States mails. The Commission authorized under this section can take necessary actions, use the United States mails, and request information from the Secretary relevant to its duties. SEC. 201. STUDY OF NEW PARK SYSTEM AREAS. Section 8 of the Act of August 18, 1970 is amended to include general authority, remove certain sentences, authorize appropriations, eliminate subsection (b), and add a new subsection (b) for studies of potential park system additions. The Act of August 18, 1970 is amended to include a new subsection (b) for studies of potential park system additions. The Secretary is required to submit a list of areas recommended for study for potential inclusion in the National Park System, giving consideration to national significance, suitability, and feasibility criteria. Special consideration is to be given to themes, sites, and resources not adequately represented in the current National Park System Plan. The National Park System Plan will identify areas not adequately represented in the current system. No new studies for potential park system additions can be initiated without specific authorization from Congress. The National Park Service can still conduct preliminary assessments and gather data on potential study areas. This section does not apply to the study of river segments for potential addition to national wild and scenic rivers. The Secretary must complete studies for potential National Park System additions within 3 fiscal years of specific legislation enactment. Studies must involve public input and consider national significance of the area. The Secretary must conduct studies to determine if an area has significant natural or cultural resources and is suitable for addition to the National Park System. Factors considered include resource rarity, threats, public use potential, costs, and socioeconomic impacts. The Secretary conducts studies to assess areas for potential inclusion in the National Park System, considering factors like resource significance, public use potential, costs, and socioeconomic impacts. Each study evaluates management options and recommends the preferred option to Congress at the beginning of each calendar year. The Secretary conducts studies on areas for potential inclusion in the National Park System, evaluating resource significance, public use potential, costs, and socioeconomic impacts. Recommendations on preferred management options are submitted to Congress annually along with a list of areas prioritized for addition to the system based on cultural or natural resources.
